solution.text:
The first term of the G.P is a and the \(_{r}_^{th}\) term is b
Let \(_{r}_=n\)
The G.P. is \(a,ar,ar^2,ar^3,...,ar^{n-1}\)
where \(r\) is the common ratio and \(ar^{n-1}=b\)
P=Product of n terms
\(P=a\times ar \times ar^2 \times ..... \times ar^{n-1} \)
\(P=(a\times a \times ... \times a) (r \times r^2 \times ..... \times r^{n-1} )\)
\(P=a^n r^{1+2+..+(n-1)}\)
Here \(1+2+..+(n-1)\) is an A.P.
Therefore,
\(1+2+..+(n-1)=\frac{n-1}{2}[2+((n-1)-1)]\)
\(1+2+..+(n-1)=n\frac{n-1}{2}\)
i.e.
\(P=a^nr^{n\frac{n-1}{2}}\)
also \(P^2=a^{2n}r^{n(n-1)}\).........(1)
now seeing on the R.H.S
\(a\times b=a \times ar^{n-1}\)
\(a\times b=a^2r^{n-1}\)...........(2)
Given
\(P^2=(a\times b)^x\)
Substituting equation (1) and (2)
\(a^{2n}r^{n(n-1)}=a^{2x}r^{x(n-1)}\)
Comparing the powers of a and r separately on L.H.S and R.H.S
\(2n=2x\)
\(n(n-1)=x(n-1)\)
from above 2 equations it is clear that x = n = _{r}_

content.text: If the first and the \(_{r}_^{th}\) term of a G.P are a and b respectively, \(P\) is the product of _{r}_ terms and \(P^2=(a\times b)^x\). Find x?
